description: From Middle English schort, short, from Old English sċeort, sċort (“short”), from Proto-West Germanic *skurt, from Proto-Germanic *skurtaz (“short”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker-.

Cognate with shirt, skirt, curt, Scots short, schort (“short”), French court, Dutch kort, German kurz, Old High German scurz (“short”) (whence Middle High German schurz), Old Norse skorta (“to lack”) (whence Danish skorte), Albanian shkurt (“short, brief”), Latin curtus (“shortened, incomplete”), Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ. Doublet of curt. More at shirt.

entries.meaning: Having a small distance from one end or edge to another, either horizontally or vertically.
(of a person) Of comparatively small height.
Having little duration.
examples: Antonym: long

entries.meaning: (followed by for) Of a word or phrase, constituting an abbreviation (for another) or shortened form (of another).
examples: "Phone" is short for "telephone" and "asap" short for "as soon as possible".

entries.meaning: (cricket, of a fielder or fielding position) that is relatively close to the batsman.
(cricket, of a ball) bowled so that it bounces relatively far from the batsman.
(golf, of an approach shot or putt) that falls short of the green or the hole.
(gambling) Of betting odds, offering a small return for the money wagered.
(baking, of pastries, metallurgy) Brittle, crumbly. (See shortbread, shortcake, shortcrust, shortening, hot short, cold-short.)
Abrupt; brief; pointed; petulant.
examples: He gave a short answer to the question.

entries.meaning: Limited in quantity; inadequate; insufficient; scanty.
examples: a short supply of provisions

entries.meaning: Insufficiently provided; inadequately supplied, especially with money; scantily furnished; lacking.
examples: to be short of money
I'd lend you the cash but I'm a little short at present.
The cashier came up short ten dollars on his morning shift.

entries.meaning: Deficient; less; not coming up to a measure or standard.
examples: an account which is short of the truth

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Undiluted; neat.
examples: Delance raised his beer and watched Hoadly throw down another swig of hard stuff. "Take it short if you want to make it over the mountain tonight."

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Not distant in time; near at hand.
examples: But, alas! he who escapes from death is not pardoned; he is only reprieved, and reprieved to a short day.

entries.meaning: (finance) Being in a financial investment position that is structured to be profitable if the price of the underlying security declines in the future.
examples: Coordinate term: long
short position
I'm short in General Motors because I think their sales are plunging.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Doubtful of, skeptical of.
(finance, dated) Of money: given in the fewest possible notes, i.e. those of the largest denomination.
examples: Antonym: long

entries.meaning: Abruptly, curtly, briefly.
examples: They had to stop short to avoid hitting the dog in the street.
He cut me short repeatedly in the meeting.
The boss got a message and cut the meeting short.

entries.meaning: Unawares.
examples: The recent developments at work caught them short.

entries.meaning: Without achieving a goal or requirement.
examples: His speech fell short of what was expected.

entries.meaning: (cricket, of the manner of bounce of a cricket ball) Relatively far from the batsman and hence bouncing higher than normal; opposite of full.
(finance) With a negative ownership position.
examples: We went short most finance companies in July.

entries.meaning: A short circuit.
A short film.
examples: Preceded by a Simpsons short shot in 3-D—perhaps the only thing more superfluous than a fourth Ice Age movie—Ice Age: Continental Drift finds a retinue of vaguely contemporaneous animals coping with life in the post-Pangaea age.

entries.meaning: A short version of a garment in a particular size.
examples: 38 short suits fit me right off the rack.
Do you have that size in a short?

entries.meaning: (baseball) A shortstop.
examples: Jones smashes a grounder between third and short.

entries.meaning: (finance) A short seller.
examples: The market decline was terrible, but the shorts were buying champagne.

entries.meaning: (finance) A short sale or short position.
examples: He closed out his short at a modest loss after three months.

entries.meaning: A summary account.
(phonetics) A short sound, syllable, or vowel.
(programming) An integer variable having a smaller range than normal integers; usually two bytes long.
(US, slang) An automobile; especially in crack shorts, to break into automobiles.
examples: For example, one addict would crack shorts (break and enter cars) and usually obtain just enough stolen goods to buy stuff and get off just before getting sick.

entries.meaning: Deficient in.
examples: We are short a few men on the second shift.
He's short common sense.

entries.meaning: (finance) Having a negative position in.
examples: I don’t want to be short the market going into the weekend.

verbs.description: short (third-person singular simple present shorts, present participle shorting, simple past and past participle shorted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause a short circuit in (something).
(intransitive, of an electrical circuit) To short circuit.
(transitive) To shortchange.
(transitive, informal) To provide with a smaller than agreed or labeled amount.
examples: This is the third time I’ve caught them shorting us.

entries.meaning: (transitive, business) To sell something, especially securities, that one does not own at the moment for delivery at a later date in hopes of profiting from a decline in the price; to sell short.
(obsolete) To shorten.
